headline: Grits, Sausage, and Egg Casserole
description: Make this delicious grits, sausage, and egg casserole for your guests and they will be begging for the recipe!
name: Grits, Sausage, and Egg Casserole

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9x13-inch baking dish.

Bring water, half-and-half, and salt to a boil in a saucepan; slowly whisk in grits. Reduce heat to low and simmer, stirring occasionally, until thick, about 20 minutes. Stir in Cheddar cheese and butter until melted. Cool.
Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Cook and stir sausage in the hot skillet until browned and crumbly, 5 to 7 minutes; drain and discard grease.
Beat eggs and milk together in a bowl. Stir sausage, egg mixture, orange bell pepper, and red bell pepper into grits mixture. Pour grits mixture into prepared baking dish.
Bake in the preheated oven until set, 45 to 60 minutes.

review.reviewBody: This was SO good and SO easy and SO delicious! I used my rice maker and a box of cream of wheat in the place of grits...If you use the rice maker for the grits/cream of wheat, be sure to give it a stir once or twice as it starts cooking...I did not do that and I had a few lumps of cream of wheat that were not really a problem...just not what would have been easily attained perfection with a simple stir or two. Otherwise, I followed all the other ingredients precisely. I mixed it all up and left it in the mixing bowl in the fridge uncovered till morning. (other review said it was too wet so I figured a little overnight evaporation would help)...then thew it in a 9X13 and into the oven at 350 when I woke up - it took about an hour to bake, and I sprinkled the top highly with some shredded cheese toward the end...more for art than anything else. I found that it was just firm enough to serve brownie stile cut portions, but I would not call it firm - but at the same time...if it were slightly undercooked...or wetter I wouldn't have enjoyed it as much...it was perfection! (short of a couple of lumps as previously mentioned.) My family LOVED, and it made GREAT leftovers, cut servings held their shape nicely. I garnished with a rose-cut tomato, basil, sour cream, balsamic reduction, and chives...just for fun. - It was worthy! -its amazing how much food 3 eggs and 1 little pack of sausage links makes! -Use the rice maker and cream of wheat! - box directions for water/wheat for 1 cup of dry cream of wheat -SO SO SO SO SO easy and fast when you do the rice maker and mix it into a bowl for overnight in fridge before baking in the AM! -This would be perfect for pre-mixing and refrigerating and baking for a cabin retreat morning! Fresh fruit, buttered toast and Jelly on the side. -nice and soft for little mouths -fun and different!

I really liked the grits before I put them in the casserole. After the casserole baked, it was flat. I’ll use this recipe for the grits, but not for the casserole. I did not add a stick of butter to the grits, zi added 2 tablespoons.
Made it as written and wouldn’t change a thing. And I’m very southern.

This is amazing!! I made half since there are two of us. Sautéed sausage in cast iron 10” and drained. Cooked half of an onion and some garlic in same pan. When grits were ready with added milk and egg I mixed everything in the same skillet. Covered with foil and baked 30 min (remember.... half recipe). Added sprinkle of extra cheese and finished in oven without foil covering. So yummy! Thanks for this recipe.
Yuuuuum!! Brought to breakfast pitch-in, was big hit!

I made this for a "breakfast for supper" meal. Very tasty! It made a larger batch than I expected, so plenty of leftovers. I was out of peppers, so I didn't add those, but I did add a chopped onion, which I cooked up with the sausage. I cooked the sausage in a 9-inch cast iron skillet, and then carefully added the cooked grits, cheese, and eggs to the pan and baked it in that instead of in a casserole dish, which saved a little on cleaning.
I made it! I left out the peppers because it was for a large group but everybody loved it! I had one lady ask for the recipe.
We love this dish, I have make it often , we like it better without the peppers

I loved finding an egg casserole that didn't use bread. I was a little concerned because none of my family members like grits but they all loved this and requested it again. I thought I had cheddar cheese on hand but ended up having to use a mixture of various shredded cheeses. Next time I will try using just cheddar, but the mix of cheeses was fabulous also.
Made it with regular grits and left the bell peppers out. Brought it to a bunch buffet at work and everyone loved it!!! Will def make again for my family

This is very good! I used quick grits because that is what I had on hand so it did not take the full 20 minutes for them to thicken. Next time I would reduce the fluid just a tiny bit (maybe 1/8 of a cup) as I think they would set better if using quick grits. This would also be fantastic with ham or bacon too or any combination of meats. In the future, I may add a tiny bit of cheese to the top the last few minutes of baking.
I will definitely make this again. It was a huge hit with my family.
We have had this every Christmas morning for the last 20 years - our sons expect it. I do use turkey sausage crumbles to save cleaning a skillet, and I add a tsp of dry mustard.

I've had this recipe for now on 30 years. It never fails to be a hit. I would make it on Sunday for brunch then the rest if the week all my kids had to do was cut a slice warm in microwave and breakfast was On!
I always double the eggs
This is one of my family's favorites. I make it only , but don;t add the bell peppers. I'll have to try it with the peppers. Thank you
This was an easy & perfect Christmas morning casserole. I used lean turkey sausage & it turned out delicious! Everyone loved it.

I made this recipe for my bible stud class and it was a huge hit. The casserole was very tasty, good texture and a hearty meal by itself. Very easy to make and I like being able to make ahead the night before actually cooking the dish. I will definitely make this recipe again.

SO GOOD!! Not too eggy like a lot of egg casseroles are. Next time I would add onion.
It says it takes 15 minutes to make, but the grits need to cook for 20. Plan on 30 minutes to make.

This is a great breakfast or brunch pot luck dish. I've made it for work twice and everyone loves it. I also add a touch of salt to the grits and sprinkle some cheese on top. I like things a bit spicy so I either use hot sausage or add a little cayenne when I mix in the sausage.

Followed recipe as described. The grits/cheese mixture was great as I was making and I thought the finished product would be delicious. But the downside for me was the 1/2 cup of butter. I think the most needed would be 1-2 tbsp. When finished, the butter made the casserole runny and the taste way too rich. I'll try again, but next time with little or no added butter.
Excellent taste AND texture! Terrific for a group.
This recipe is absolutely delicious. I couldn't find the stone ground grits so I just used the 2 1/2 minute quick grits. So good.

Made it this morning for breakfast for six teenagers and they gobbled it up. Luckily, there were two servings left, so I was able to get a taste. Its very good and was ready after 45 minutes baking. I used linked sausage, cut to bite sizes since I didn't have loose sausage on hand. Will be making again!

This is such a delicious way to make grits! All of the ingredients are perfectly balanced! I did add a touch of salt while cooking the grits and saved a bit of cheese to top the casserole. Baked perfectly in 45 minutes for me. Will be making this again! Would be great for company and brunch!
